Now newsreels were purely artifacts. They were not intended to show reality. They were intended to show,
to give an impression which would be sensational, but would at the same time also be propaganda.
And therefore you never really got reality then. But once television came and it was completely sort of,
you know, fair play, it learned on the job. It got more and more expert at getting there quickly
and taking the pictures. Oh no, Aberfan was one of those occasions. Because another one, you see,
which came on television second hand, was the Kennedy assassination in 1963, which was run and run
and run. And I don't think earlier I would ever have really seen the Kennedy assassination in my
mind's eye. But by the time you've seen it five times on television, the image of the head going back,
the image of the car, so on and on, I have a profound respect and fear of television.
